author: Colin Althaus
content:
Now if you put this HPF on only the Side channel, at 100Hz what was originally +S becomes -S (180 degrees out of phase). So any 100Hz on the left now shifts to the right, and vice versa.

So say you have a rack tom with a fundamental at 100Hz panned hard left. Apply this filter to the S channel and its 100Hz fundamental will sound like it’s coming out of the right side. But the top end of the tom will still sound like it’s coming from the left.

Very extreme example, but seen this happen IRL more than once. Easiest to hear this on headphones if you’d like to experiment.

I’ve found the easiest way to avoid this is to use very gentle M-S slopes (gentle = less phase shift), shelves and bells, and especially avoid any steep HPF or LPF (18 dB/oct or greater).

author: Matt Huber
content:
Ah yes. The monthly tailspin, I know it well 😂

One thing that I have found to be very helpful to reduce masking / increase clarity  is to simply start by going track to track and listening for / EQing out non musical resonances and non-musical buildups. 

I am definitely NOT suggesting the aggressive hyper notching you see in a lot of YouTube tutorials, but a general track to track cleanup of obvious issues. Don’t over think it, only attack the obvious things 

Hypothetical Examples:
- weird 1.5k resonant ring in the hats and overheads…notch that thing down a bit. You’d be surprised how much space that takes up in a dense mix. 
- high lead guitar part with extraneous rumble at 200hz…not contributing to the musicality of the part…byeeee
- piano building up at 300hz in the choruses when everything is competing for midrange - automate EQ in chorus to create space 


Etc etc etc. 

Small moves like that have made some of the biggest differences for me. Definitely not the fanciest tip, but simple EQ moves have been the biggest contributor to midrange clarity for me.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
@BoozleBAM This is a GREAT question, and having read the whole convo twice I don't think it was really answered. Honestly I probably won't be able to answer it either, but here are some thoughts in no particular order

First the usual caveat, I'm not a mixer and I haven't mixed a record in a decade. But I did record and mix for 20 years before that and followed the whole arc from beginner not understanding compression, to pro finding my way and getting to own or use all of the baller dream hardware. All that to say I have a lot of empathy for where you are at with it. These are not definitive statements, just aspects to think about..

1) First something of a hot take that I don't see represented online. IMO compression often makes an individual instrument sound "worse". If you play and record something like drums well or acoustic guitar well, a compressed version will often sound *less real* and less vital. So why in the world would we do it???

- The first reason is that we mostly don't care about how individual instruments sound, we care about the whole song. Often a compressed sound will play nicer in an arrangement than something dynamic, real and recorded in a "documentarian" way

- The second reason is a trade off that isn't often spoken about. Compressed instruments often translate better into the wild. Take a beautiful, dynamic, real sounding, hifi & documentarian recording of say upright bass, drums and acoustic guitar. Listen in your studio in great monitors and it's a dream. Now go to Target and play it in mono on the overhead speaker on a busy saturday.....it just won't survive ... the song gets lost. Or drive with your window open, or cook dinner with the AC on etc etc.

author: cian riordan
content: Hell yea. I'd start by having a relatively dry kit in a relatively dry space. The snare is tuned up pretty high but somewhat dead... avoiding the big 150-300hz fundamental that a lot of indie records are chasing these days. It's a very Nigel Godrich-y compression sound which is -- not really the sound of compression on the snare mic, but more on the kit as a whole. You'll notice that the whole kit, cymbals included, is really getting pressed up against whatever compression is happening. And to make that work, the drummer is playing very lightly... even on the heavier chorus sections. I'd probably start with a pair of 1176s or an 1178 strapped across the kit... medium attack and fast release (or heavier handed on a parallel bus) and you'll get that great snap from such a light touch.

author: cian riordan
content: Also what @Zack Hames said, downbeat automation is big. If something is loud at the very beginning of a section, then comes back down in volume, the ear will perceive it to be loud for the section. So quickly automating drums + cymbals, big piano chords, guitars, etc -- just for a moment -- will go a long way at making sections exciting. I'm also a fan of slowly lowering the volume of certain instruments right before section changes to give the perception of loudness and excitement on the downbeat.

author: Colin Althaus
content:
In the acoustic guitar example this *is* what’s happening, but with MS it’s not *always* what happens.

With a single stereo source that has a strong in-phase center, MS tends to work more like you’d expect from the words ‘mid’ and ‘side’.

In this case you’re cutting the in-phase (summable) low mids from the M channel. What’s left is the out-of-phase (difference) low mids on the S channel.

Like Jonathan said, things get weird when you have different, un-centered content on L and R. A sound hard panned to the left or right will sum to mono AND create a difference between L and R, so it shows up equally in both M and S channels. Processing only the S creates incoherence from the M part of the source, which can have unintended effects when you sum back to LR. An extreme example being a panned tom with the fundamental ending up on the opposite side.

In my experience MS processing has the potential to be quite destructive on a stereo mix for this reason.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Nowadays I am committing tracks sooner and sooner in the process. It's partly a result of me feeling more assured in my choices, and partly me aiming to reduce the complexity of my sessions as I proceed through them. I hate large sessions.

Nothing is more demoralizing than that feeling of being in the final mix and still auditioning new kick drum samples at the final hour. I had a production/mix like that last year and it drove me crazy because nothing felt locked in. I had no fixed point in the mix to work from or to build off of.

Nowadays whenever I think to myself "This _ feels great and like a finished record" I will immediately commit it to audio to prevent myself from unraveling the work I've already done.

I'm the type of person that if I saw a channel with twelve plugins on it I get suspicious and start paring it back to see if I can create the sound with less processing. Sometimes this is the right move, but if I start tweaking the compressor in the 2nd plugin slot that's downstream of 8 more plugins that's a good way to de-stabilize the entire sound you've built up. Committing sooner prevents me from unraveling too much of the audio.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Here’s the one other thing about Serban that I think is obvious, but seemingly overlooked a lot

There’s a trade off between dynamic control/having things locked in place, and allowing things to be wilder. Mixes where things are locked in place sound more similar everywhere, they are in a sense robust. Mixes with braver dynamic or EQ choices can be much more exciting under ideal conditions, but do less well at the edges of the bell curve (mono overhead speaker at the supermarket for example)

Serban’s mixes are very locked in place, dynamically and from a frequency point of view and so he has great translation. I rarely find it to get in the way of the song, but some of my mixer friends will go to the mat about how it could have been so much more …. And maybe they’re right

But if you win the race, and the song comes through then how much more do you need to win it by? His mixes do the job of getting pop songs into my ears, and give A&R confidence and comfort, a lot to like …

author: BatMeckley
content: Make a new duplicate snare track. Gate the hell out of it. Also band pass it to roughly the frequency that’s bumming you out. Use that as your side chain key. You can bring the gain up or down to affect the threshold. On soothe use the high and low pass filter to further narrow down the offending frequency, and then use a bell eq and raise or lower it at 10k to affect the threshold. (That’s essentially soothes threshold setting). You got this.

author: sethmanchester
content: I used to do consistent audiobook work 15+ years ago to supplement studio work. It was brutal work and I hated it. RX didn’t exist yet, or was in it’s infancy and sounded terrible. I’d record and edit, used an m930 because of the low self noise which was huge for me around the time. My editing trick was to make a 5 min room tone loop the length of the book, duplicate the dialog, strip silence one track, using the dup track as a trigger to extract silence for the other track with the room tone selected, delete the dup track. In object mode select all the audio then it’s something like shift + drag to fill the gaps from strip silence with the extracted room tone. Always used beat detective to do batch cross fades. Then listen through and correct to taste. RX declick would have been a game changer back then but I did all that shit by hand, if there was a pop on a word you’d aim to find a similar syllable somewhere else to replace it with. At the time I was getting paid $250/finished hour for editing and $300 for tracking which was really good considering I could edit around 1.5:1 but tracking was always closer to 3:1. Budgets started shrinking right around the advent of RX. When I started, there was always an engineer, producer and proofer in the room for tracking. All lunches paid for. After enough experience I was able to provide all three which made it pretty lucrative. But the industry changed and eventually it was just engineer and reader which put a lot of pressure on the engineer to produce and proof. The  publisher I worked with stopped paying for lunch then dropped my fee to $250/$200 then $225/$175 then $200/$150 and once it hit $175/$125 I saw the writing on the wall and vowed never to do it again. I will say it upped my Pro Tools keyboard speed tremendously and kept my studio afloat early on. The halycon days of audiobook production are long gone as far as finaces are concerned.

author: cian riordan
content: Fun arguments being had here. I'm firmly in the 'good songs ≠ good mixes'. I think the two can co-exist separately. There are mixes that I listen to that are empirically good (Nice To Meet ya by Megan Trainor comes to mind). It's a Jon mix and it bangs. But the song sucks. Says nothing. Completely forgettable. But it crushes the air coming out of the speakers. There are songs that I love that have terrible mixes. The first Beach House album is one of my desert island records... but technically, it sounds like they stuck an Mbox in the microwave. A lot of great cooking analogies to be had, but if mixing is like cooking, you can still have a bulletproof recipe, completely mess up the cook, and somehow end up with something delicious (Pizza, Macaroni and Cheese, etc). But then when you get Thomas Keller in the kitchen, the food will really sing, and you'll taste things you've never tasted, and feel emotions you didn't know you could feel. Thats what a good mix can do.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
This is a great question, and honestly I don’t think numbers correlate very well track to track, though @sethearnest’s answer *feels* close to me, and his work sorta shows he knows what he’s about. 

I feel like I’m currently starting to find a groove with allowing the top to *be* lower than it *feels*, and it has everything to do with relationships within a track. 

The key that unlocked this for me was starting from the brightest thing in the mix, in my case, it’s almost always vocals. Then I start marrying the other things I want to match that. Everything else gets tanked. Shakers & Tambos and acoustics are WAY darker than they used to be for me, it’s basically vocal & snare that share the top of the record. 

The elements that live on the sides, those can start to creep up there too, but that’s a taste/track thing that varies. 

So as long as the right elements are in properly relationship with your focal instrument, the top can live almost anywhere.

I was having a conversation with Cavallo the other day and he was telling me his mix process that he learned, and it was basically “I just go left to right. First I bring up the kick. author: Slow Hand
content:
This reminds me of an important point: Most sounds in the mix don't actually need to be stereo. And a snare drum is probably not one of them. You can create a lot of space in your mix by reducing all but a few key elements to mono. Keyboards and synths are a huge offender here.

A lot of mixers/producers assume that the instruments need to be stereo, when in fact it's the *mix* that should be stereo. And the most "stereo" mix is often created by panning mono instruments in the stereo field. Getting those pan balances right is going to remove a lot of conflict between instruments sharing similar frequency ranges.

You can still have stereo reverbs and echoes, but they can often be far more narrow than the default setting of 100% width. So don't overlook narrowing your stereo elements too.

It's amazing how much you can do with nothing but faders, pan knobs, and EQ.

Another option here is just simply the performance. Four on the floor is actually really hard to get right, especially under the microscope of a multi mic’d scenario where the low end can vastly change depending on how hard the drummer is hitting. If you hit a kick or snare a little too hard or if the drummer is flamming their kick and snare hits, it can choke the drum, kill the low end, and maybe present itself as being out of phase. But if flipping the phase is solving the issue, I guess it is phase related, which is interesting. 

FWIW, if it is performance related and I know the artist is down for me to be surgical, sometimes I’ll just fly a good hit from the previous bar to replace the one that was flam’d or choked or sounds out of phase. I know this doesn’t work for every scenario, and some drummers might hate that if they found out, but I find that usually does the trick for me and blends in really naturally to a performance.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Also, we say "there are no rules" a lot. But actually that's not nuanced enough for my taste (and perhaps, this place).

There are many great "rules." Yes, some are dumb and some are wrong, but many of them are worth learning so you know how to break them.

Things like "cut eq before you compress, boost after" is a really great rule. When you learn to do it and to hear it, you learn why it's so important (pulling low end plosives out of a vocal so it doesn't pin the compressor, for example). From there you learn how and when to break it (I like boosting the 200hz-ish body of a live snare drum into a parallel compressor/ saturator to solidify and have control of that frequency range, automate it for fills, etc.).

IMO this is a great "rule," which is great to learn and then break all the time.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
- The classic example of compression is to use a fast release with something like a parallel drum buss. As the release lets go and brings up the room gain you get this urgent and explosive energy. When the room is good, and the compression timing is set right it can really make things sound bigger than real life. Remember we're trying to tell a story here, we can't jam the *actual* real power and size of stadium rock drums into that mono speaker at Target but listen to Paradise City and it tells the story pretty well ... our brain does an amazing job of filling in the rest

- The last example is using something like a good tube compressor on vocals. With a nice soft knee and lots of gain reduction we get bring up a bunch of low level and emotional detail, breathy whispery stuff at the end of lines etc that can really help a lyric connect. Often with something like a good tube compressor we get a healthy amount of harmonic distortion too along for the ride which adds weight to the vocal and draws the listeners attention

-tighten the snares until the responded how you want

author: Maxim
content:
I’d say when all efforts have been exhausted to try and get stems you’ve only got a few options depending on how “badly” the beat is mixed. But generally my approach might look something like this: First pull down the volume by a bunch. Then usually you’ll want to add in some transients back again. I like Spiff for this to taste. Then sometimes Master Rebalance by Ozone can be a life saver. Especially if say the balance of some instruments are clashing with the vocal or the 808/bass is too loud in relation to everything else. Essentially I’m “unlimiting the beat”. 

Then together with the vocal in the mix I’ll try to shape the beat around the vocal with some subtle (usually reductive) eq moves. Something like dynamically sidechaining a bell on the hihat frequencies to the vocal can help a lot. Or I might also play with Spectral Shape. Some people get good results with sidechaining the vocal as a whole with trackspacer or soothe. Then if I’m missing some super lows or excitement I might throw a Pultec/Bax-type EQ or Spectre on it. 

So ultimately I’m creating as much space as possible and give myself enough headroom to still do some typical mixbus moves.

To me this removes the need to do anything different on the mixbus. Even though it’s likely I won’t be able to push as hard.

author: cian riordan
content:
Couple of random thoughts:
1. If the synth is extremely subby, consider pushing in some midrange via EQ or saturation to help definite it in the mix. Sometimes these synth basses are swimming in sub and the more you turn them up, the more it eats up headroom while still not really being able to hear it.
2. Are you competing against other low end sources outside of the kick? If so, you’ll have to divide and conquer the frequency ranges and let each one live in a specific zone. For example, if you have a bass guitar, make sure that its voiced in the fundamental 200-400hz area and leave the sub handle things below the kick.
3. Utilizing the analyzer in Pro-Q3 can be helpful for finding conflicting frequencies. You can throw Pro-Q3 on say the synth bass and the kick track, then on the synth bass instance, pull up the kick as a secondary histogram in Pro-Q3 and you’ll have a nice visual representation of where the kick is trying to punch through. You can then use some creative cutting to carve room for the kick. Or vice-versa.
4. Sometimes when nothing is working with synth bass and I need to do something drastic, I’ll delay one side of it 30mz to widen it out and get it out of the center. This can fall apart in certain mono-situations, but will often clear way for more bass instruments and the kick drum if done right.

As always, all of this is dependent on everything. YMMV.

author: Eric Martin
content:
I think, again, it’s knowing the reason you’re using the tool, it’s mostly used when you want to accomplish something on the sides or in the mono signal when you can’t get to the track that needs the help, if your mixing, you should go to the track that needs the work first, not a M/S tool, M/S tools are designed for working on stereo tracks and shaping things because you CANT shape the original thing you want.

Example, the vocal is a little quiet in the mix, using a M/S tool to help bring the 1-2k of the vocal out in the mid without bringing out too much 1-2k of the cymbals and guitars on the sides because that balance was already where you wanted it. In this situation you can’t get to the vocal because you don’t have the track, BUT if you’re mixing, you can reach for the vocal and boost a narrow Q at 1500hz to accomplish the same task but in a cleaner way.

This is the type of reason I might reach for M/S, I don’t reach for M/S if guitars need to be brighter on the sides, I find the guitars on the sides in my mix, and make them brighter.

This is also the same reason to argue against multiple bus processing, because if the ability to use such a processor is there, we will use it, take away a bus and we have to work harder to get the mix done, but the end result can be much more effective, impactful, dynamic, and inspiring, but it takes longer and requires a lot more finesse.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Rules for giving notes. 
1) start with what you like, but be brief.
2) “kick up” 👍🏻 “I feel like the kick is too thin” or “boost 50hz” 👎🏻 
3) mixers expect notes, so approach every communication collaboratively. 
4) if something is wrong but you’re not sure what it is, call and discuss. 

Basically not everything needs an explanation, not everything needs to be handled gently. “Kick up, drier verse vocal, longer snare tail, brighter vocal.”

author: cian riordan
content: This “pre-gain staging your template” thing sounds like you’d be backing yourself into even more trouble. Templates are meant to be flexible and you’ll always need to make adjustments to make things work for the track. Let’s say you calibrate your drum bus for 1 dB of gain reduction — what does that do to account for the overall mean volume of those drums? The frequency density? It’s such a weird esoteric metric to try and quantify the signal you’re sending through it. Best thing you could do is setup your template to be able to do broad stroke gain adjustments within, very quickly, to get your chains hitting the way you like.

A couple things to note:

-You can use this technique to get a fairly large range of tunings while still having dead/controlled overtones...try tuning the lugs beside the loose lug and also mess with the lugs directly across from the loose set of lugs.

-It does not work well for all playing styles (rolls and some of the more detailed stuff can feel+sound weird to play)

-The snare wires will respond differently depending on what pitch you tune it to so you will need to make adjustments to the wire tension to get it dialed perfect (this is true any way you tune the snare and is often overlooked)

author: bobby k
content:
Ryan called me yesterday to geek out about a MELD workflow for buss compression. It essentially allows you to compile what’s contributing to the sidechain, and trim up/down certain elements post compression without affecting how the compressor is behaving. I used this for a drum buss yesterday and it was super neat. 

For me if im wanting a slammed buss sound I’m typically gaining down all drum mics that aren’t shells as I lean into the compressor. This let me instead trim up the shells post compression to the same effect. I then messed with just the oheads & crotch feeding the detector to see if the kick and snare was making stuff too pumpy.

I’m still wrapping my mind around this technique and I’d be curious to hear some of you guys weigh in on how you’ve found sidechaining effective in a live drum buss format!

author: sethearnest
content:
For sync most of the time they want actual sub-mixed stems per inst group, not multitracks, so a drum mix, bass, guitars, etc, as separate stems all adding up to the stereo mix. So whatever’s a part of the busses /subgroups adding up to the stereo mix should be left on. 

The reason why: Most of the time they’ll use the stereo mix in my experience, but if something like a shaker or lead synth is wailing away under a dialog moment, or something like a boomer is messing up a sound effect, they’ll bust into the stems to mute those conflicting elements, but they’ll want the song/mix to generally sound the same. 

So for sync stems, they may have deliverable specs already, so doesn’t hurt to ask, but if not, I always try to put myself in the mind of an editor and approach stem splits with the idea of “if it could be distracting, it gets its own stem.” Generally, aside from basic inst groups, I’ll split out high perc stuff, boomer/swooshers/lifters, any leads/solos, and of course vocals always get split lead and BGVs as separate stems.

author: Deleted User
content:
1. Corrective EQ in the Upper midrange/high end, notching out all the harsh resonances, taming the pick transients if the bass is played with a pick. I love the way MAAT Santa Cruz does this ever so smoothly. 
2. I compress the bass with a compressor sidechained to a LPF(!), to get some low end body which is usually severely lacking. The LPF is set between 1000-2000 hz, attack 0-8 ms and release 200-400 ms depending on the tempo of the song/bass part. Reducing 3-5 dB on peaks. This gets me really far.
3. If the bass is a shortscale, I’ll use Goodhertz Tiltshift to move the low mids from around 200 hz to around 100 hz, out of the way of the guitars. 
4. Then I put an amp emulation on the channel. Whichever one floats your boat. Plugin Alliance B15, Guitar Rig, TSE BOD, whatever. I’ll be boosting low end and cutting high end here, or before with a separate instance of Tiltshift. 
5. If I want the bass to sound „rock“ and cut, I send it to a parallel distortion, which can be anything. I like TSE BOD, which is another sansamp copy which  has a lot of sub. My trick here is to add a clipper before the sansamp to really get extra gnarl. Logic‘s stock Bitcrusher works great, but I’m sure anything works.

content:
It’s also worth listening if it’s attack portion or the sustain that is getting buried. 

If there is not enough attack on the bass, you can sometimes trigger sample (percussive sample, sometimes a really short foley thing) that has the right presence area to have a little something that adds a punch to the bass. I often just copy one note that works into other parts that don’t cut through but this stuff only works sometimes. It doesn’t really work with busier bass parts

And sustain wise, compression can help when it’s done right or make it worse when it isn’t done right. Same with saturation. I think with sustain, there’s a lot of nuance in how you want the sustain to sit- performance is a huge part of this. Sometimes there’s too much bright stuff and it doesn’t allow the sustain to be audible, if you can tell something’s down there but you can’t really feel it or hear it that might be the issue. I noticed when there’s too much or wrong compression on other upper elements, it becomes an issue. 

Also dup the track and start new and see where you can take it, sometimes there’s too much going on and hard to track what’s causing what.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
If I'm totally rebalancing drums, I'll treat them as if I'm tracking them myself and building a basic working drum sound.This *usually* goes as follows, and I like to do it *very* quickly (as if the drummer is in the live room playing and everyone's waiting):

1. Mute everything.
2. Pull up kick in and out (+ sub or whatever they've recorded). Play with balance and phase of kick out until it feels good (good is context dependent - sometimes that's deep/subby/slow, sometimes that's punchy/percussive etc).
4. Bring up overheads along with kick mics. Flip overhead phase and play with balance til it sounds cool, or punchy, or whatever you're after. Sometimes there's a very obvious right or wrong answer, but often just figure out whatever works for the drum groove + arrangement + song. Where the bass sits can often help tell you what config will work best.
5. Solo snare mics, get them in phase with each other (just listen together and flip usually snare bottom until the blend sounds cool to you - often I'm looking for whichever configuration has more "thud", but that's context dependent). 
6.Unsolo and check snares against kicks and overheads. If you need to flip the snares, flip both top and bottom (or whatever combo) together so their relative phase remains intact. 
6. Add in rooms, again flipping and balancing til shit feels cool. Do same for crush mics, any other flavour stuff.

Toms are usually my last concern. Unless the groove is tom heavy, they might do only 2 or 3 hits across the whole song, so as Ryan said - hand gate those fuckers and deal with them once the general sound is dialled in.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
+1 on Trigger Gate from Ryan’s recommend.

The Oxford drum gate is also pretty unique in how you can have frequency dependent release - ie the fundamental of the snare can ring on longer, but the crack happens then disappears before the hihat wash becomes over exaggerated 

BX SSL 4k gate can be very precise (and in Fast mode you can use the “snap” as it opens as part of the sound), but I’m in the habit of creating separate gate trigger versions of the kick and snare - super heavily gated (and filtered + compressed) versions of the kick in and snare top. 

I commit the processing on those, mute them but then have them pre fade sending to SC Kick and SC Snare buses. Super handy for lots of functions - either very precise and malleable gate open and close on the audible drums themselves, but also for instrument sidechains, maybe Pro-MB ext input on a bass track, a sine generator under the kick / noise generator on snare, the Slate Trigger feeds etc. 

Having the gate triggers as audio allows you to slide them a couple samples back and forth as needed for groove or faux lookahead. 

Maybe there’s easier ways to do things (it’s a somewhat old school technique), but making them is one of my prep steps and they do get used in every session.

author: LAPhill
content:
There's a distinction worth making between experimenting (at any stage of the process) and waffling. I've seen whole scores get changed at the 11th hour because, two days before wrapping, they discovered a better melody and then had to go change every cue that had it. There was quick decision-making in the "oh shit, we all agree this is actually better," but keeping the doors open to new ideas until the very last minute. 

My point is that inspiration can strike at any point. Hearing a great mix might reveal a more unique arrangement idea, or new harmonies, etc. etc... And I don't think there's anything wrong with that, we're all in service of the music. But there's an ocean of difference between that and "I played this for the receptionist at my sister-in-law's car dealership and she thought the kick drum was too loud, so I think we should revisit it"

What does floppy kick mean?

I had good luck with Smack Attack recently on a kick with excessively long low end that hung around after the hit.

author: Slow Hand
content:
So I'm hearing two things: You're having difficulty knowing how to get what you want (over or under processing) and you're not feeling confident about the choices that you're making.

If you hadn't already mentioned it, my first thought would be to evaluate your monitoring because it sounds as if you're missing the mark that you're aiming at (over/under processing). But it also sounds like you are split on the target that you're trying to hit in the first place.

When the production you're given to mix is lacking in some way - maybe the sonics aren't great, the arrangement isn't great, or the song is not great - there can be an urge as mixer to want to close that gap by delivering a killer mix. Sometimes we see that gap and think that we'll be able to make this record amazing and make up for it's shortcomings by crushing the mix. But there's only so far that we can take a song at the mix stage. Maybe the record will be great anyways despite some perceived issue.

While there's always room for improvement take care that you're not putting all of that weight on your shoulders. By all means do a great job, but know when to stop chasing an unattainable goal. It's not necessarily something that you can resolve as mixer. So - if that's the case - make sure you're not demanding the world from yourself.

yeah ive had it since it came out, same with soothe1 and all similar tools, @Joel "Roomie" Berghult was right. I tend to buy plugins to save time when projects come in. 

In the order I'd range these kind of tools mentioned here:

As much as I want to simplify my workflow, 90% of the job is audio janitorial, I go back to simple eq, compression, fader...

author: Josh Bowman
content:
For rock and folk music I generally just do subgroups like drums, bass, guitars, leads, bvs, lvs. For pop oriented songs generally more split out/ kick, snr, toms, hats, cymbals, fx, different synths split out etc. i just use soundflow scripts that solo and bounce what I tell it to and run it at night or at lunch. Freezing tracks first can make it go way faster. As for mixbuss, I take off my final limiter (or turn down the input, however the song was sent to mastering)… I’m usually not compressing the buss hard enough for it to matter. Sometimes the sum of the stems ends up sounding better than the mix! Generally people are using them for their MD to create a live show, or for dance remixes etc. For sync most people seem happy with instrumental and accapella in my experience so far?  Also if your trying to key your mix buss compressor from a printed mix, freezing most of the session first (besides fx etc and aux tracks) seems to help the side chain feel pretty close to what the mix was. I don’t bother with it though most of the time as I’m doing a couple db at most on the buss comp.

Edit: one other idea I’ve messed with pre soundflow, is, if your just doing subgroups and have the routing setup, save your mixbuss as a track preset and when your ready to print recall it on all your masters and commit the tracks. It works for me unless im using too much uad etc.

author: Maxim
content: I wouldn’t use more than 2 bands on vocals anyways to avoid unnecessary crossover points. One band to control everything under say 1k and one band to control above could already give you interesting results. I would also keep the settings pretty much identical and only use a low ratio (2.1 or below). The idea is to let the compression trigger based of how the vocal performance might change in the lower and higher registers throughout the song. Of course this is pretty useful with problematic performances. But maybe not something to slap on by default.

author: ALXCPH
content:
That is true, but I think a good mix still sounds bad in target 😅 and I’ve been in enough bars and restaurants that have playback systems that sound worse than my iPhone in a bathroom only playing out the left speaker. 

And people will still say, “omg I love this song” and start bouncing their head.

 I believe that great songs translate every and anywhere. But fidelity cannot IMO be appreciated in these specific places. 

Ofc there are exceptions. But try eating at a restaurant on a beach promenade in south Spain and the restaurant next to you has a speaker 20 inches from your head blasting a different song. And tell me you think the vocal is warm or the drums are punchy. I think, sadly for general non music fans what they find in music, is less quiteness it’s not even about the song. 

Whereas I think the people who enjoy music, will appreciate that extra punchy drum sound or warm vocal and deep bass. And I believe those people use headphones 80% of the time. They might have a great speaker system at home. But how much time do we really have at home listening to said speakers? Headphones are with us on the go all the time. Everyone I know under 30. Listens primarily on headphones. Or their iPhone speaker. Sometimes a JBL at the beach or park, and every now and then a party speaker at a party while drunk. The ones who really really love music, either have an old vintage speaker set from their parents or a Sonnos/smart speaker type thing. 

I still believe mixing for speakers is important, and @Nomograph Mastering has a great point in speakers translating to headphones easier than vice versa. But I always make sure shit sounds amazing on my AirPods. I’d rather sacrifice something in the speaker than the AirPods. But then again. I don’t have the accolades you do. So I might be shooting myself in the foot. But that is my general philosophy.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
If it's really upsetting me I might deal with it early, but I prefer to live with those details as I get the drum mix together - there's (usually) going to be bus compression, maybe added fake Oceanway room, samples and their idiosyncracies - so many variables, all often getting processed on drum bus (+ potential parallels per song section).

By the time I'm done with that it usually just feels more like a general vibe than an exercise in precision - the snare ring in the left room mic might draw the ear away from the kick flam in the right (or that flam could now groove in a cool way as the comps breathe, or it slaps against a rhythm guitar part or whatever), but I can always go back and Time Adjuster (or L/R EQ with Fab or whatever) the rooms if they're really bothering me.

Same reason I don't usually address snare rings until I've got the drums working well

author: JustinLeu
content: I really don't want to get in the weeds on anything....if you don't think this is a good use of someones time to look at, feel free to delete this 👍  The only point I was trying to make is that there is a lot contributing to how frequencies add up. The "absolute" relationship between all microphones recording one drum will remain the same. Where things can get more complex is when drums are flaming...sometimes they add up in a pleasing way, sometimes they don't. When  the kick starts slightly ahead of the snare or vice verca it just adds up differently right? Live drums make complex tones and depending on the hit even the tone/pitch slightly changes. Lining up the hits (fixing the flams however you can make it work) changes the phase relationship. The most common thing I do is replace with a good (all lined up) hit when I can, or line them up. The phase flip mostly is done with bass notes (for me), but I 100% have found it to be a solution for some weird drum hit before....I attached a screen capture of some flams (from a really sloppy ccm recording)  just to help illustrate the potential problem.

author: BatMeckley
content:
I think it’s really important to not confuse a shitty drummer flamming with “phase relationship”. Especially because lining up a snare hit on a live kit to not flam will actually fuck with phase relationships. 

Again the screen shot shows a poor drum hit, not a phase issue per se, which AGAIN was the original point of gaspards post was that he was intermittently flipping phase on certain hits. That’s a very different thing then linking up a snare hit to not flam. 

This kinda feels like when my friend was making a movie and she kept authoritatively and confidently telling the composer to turn down the reverb and after a week in frustration she brought the stems to me and I got to go “oh. You mean tremolo”.

author: Edward Rivera
content:
If you have room mics, you're going to want to delay them in order to simulate the heard experience of the instrument in that room. The mic itself will capture the sound signature of the ambience, but the delay will give the perception of that ambience. 

Think of a drum kit in a room, and you've got a room mic on the far end of said room. The sound of the drum is going to travel across the room and into that mic, but it needs to travel _back_ to the drummer in order to be perceived. That's what the delay will do

author: Zach Hughes
content: I recently revisited a mix I initially did in 2021 for an as of yet unreleased project. A folk / rock / americana track. My OG mix had this really aggressive edge to it that I kinda liked but it also felt way too scooped in the low mids. I checked out my old session and turns out I had cranked a ton of 8khz on the mixbus (a move I haven't felt compelled to do since 2021). Related I've been really enjoying thick / dense / full bodied mixes that still have excitement / edge up top especially for vocals and I had previously struggled to achieve a similar 'heft' in my own mixes compared to what I was hearing. I think in the past I was too quick to zap low mid resonances in my vocals / guitars. So I've been experimenting cutting less down around 200hz-600hz and emphasizing more. But then I felt I was losing some of that edge / excitement by see-sawing too much with the low mids relative to up top. I've found cutting some 170hz clears much of that up for me (like oh hey there's my snare or more room for kick / bass), I achieve the thickness above in that 200-600hz range and balance that with the excitement around ~8khz. Pushing and pulling.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Warmth

Alters the frequency-dependant characteristics of the limiter’s detector circuit.

A big part of Faraday Limiter’s thick, punchy sound is its frequency-dependent gain reduction. Low and high frequency sounds hit the limiter differently, and — depending on the Warmth setting — will exhibit different attack/release characteristics. High values, such as 100%, generally sound thicker and punchier, while low values, like -100%, have a quick, bright limiter sound.

For example, you can often use the warmth control to emphasize different aspects of a snare drum: more Warmth gives more thud & low end; less Warmth gives more stick & snare presence.

The Warmth control is not EQ, and will not change the frequency response of the plugin.

author: Adam Thein
content: To expand on this idea, I’ve also had good luck with making a sine wave with a pitch envelope similar to like an 808 or more of an edm kick and start with it tuned to the kick drum fundamental and pitch downward - I haven’t had a ton of luck personally with using the tuning of the key of the song cause it becomes pretty boomy.  Also I’ve had good luck taking that pitch envelope sine or triangle and throwing a volume shaper (I use Devious Machines Duck) and sidechain that to the kick in mic, play with the shape so that it doesn’t interact with the transient, or print the whole thing to audio and play around with the timing so your sub is slightly behind the beat so your kick transient can still remain clear and your sub can bloom behind the transient.  Depends a lot on what your bass instruments are doing also but something to try!

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Are they apparent when all of the mics are in? Sometimes that stuff is better addressed on the bus. Have you engaged drum bus processing (if any)? Sometimes thickening and/or darkening the drum bus (Pultec 100Hz, Studer Tape, whatever) renders this upper mid/high stuff less abrasive.

Sometimes addressing too much of this stuff sucks life out of drums. I leave most mad snare ringing in as I work on the drums - it often winds up being cool stuff to add to the pumping energy with heavier parallel compressors, or distortions.

Is it apparent/interfering with the mix as a whole?

author: Adam Thein
content:
Is the kick note decaying too slowly?  Like if it decayed faster would it be workable, or are you trying to find a way to move the pitch down?

I’d try a soothe sidechained to an original copy of the kick close mic(s) and try and get that to pull the kick’s decay off the room and overheads, then you can play with repitching the kick close mics depending on bleed or combining with a volume shaper like the Cableguys thing or Duck or LFO Tool, something that can use the audio input as the detection circuit and try and shorten the kick as much as you can get away with and then if you have to layer in something like a clean sine wave gated to the kick to get the note you are looking for.

Definitely not without a lot of tradeoffs on the way but some combination of that has worked for me in the past in a pinch

author: cuba1956
content:
Dear friends, I have a question about sidechain in the stereo compression. Probably a weird one, but I think I'm missing something.
I've been looking into SSL Bus comp schematic — there are several going around the internet and based on what I see in SSL 500 unit are quite interesting in a way how the sidechain envelope follower is generated.
There are several approaches I see in various models:
1. Original SSL mixes left and right channels with OR principle — basically the envelope is generated based on the strongest signal coming from either L or R channels. 
2. Some of the models suggest mixing left and right channels — essentially you get the average signal between channels which is then generates into an envelope.
3. True stereo (or rather dual mono with a single set of settings) — which calculates envelopes for the left and right channels independently.
Some SSL comp models have a switch to trigger between various modes, but if I understand correctly, none of the SSL original models have used true stereo (fully independant) sidechain processing.

Drums - dark red

Piano - blue

author: Rollmottle
content:
Twas me...VU meters are very useful tools because of their relative nature. If you know where the sweet spot of a compressor is on a drum bus for example, you can calibrate 0 on the VU meter to that sweetspot. then mixing into your compressor isn't such a guessing game every time (because you get the needle bouncing around 0, not too far under or not too far over). 

i use a digital one on the way out when i'm hitting my analog chain so everything goes out at the relative same level. i use an analog one on the way back in calibrated to a "safe" level and i know when it's coming back in ultra hot or i need a little extra gain to get it to the sweet spot. when you're monitoring stays at a consistent level, VU meters can help you judge relative relationships quite easily. i could see it being useful in the use case you described if you've calibrated the VU accordingly. say you want to generally hit -10 at the mixbus...calibrate a -10 signal to 0 on the VU. everything you then feed into the mixbus will show on the VU + or - where you want to end up.

I started using them itb after Leon Zervos who masters at 301 where I work but used to work at Sterling (where he mastered classics like mambo nr 5, the macarena, Avril Lavigne, Maroon 5 etc.) recommended them & spoke about the same “dancing” thing that @spectrummasters spoke about. The other engineer showed me the same thing this time with a powerful lead vocal. This was kinda back when the loudness wars were still a bit more relevant & when I delivered quiter mixes & left them more space to do their thing & these energy bursts limited the final loudness potential. Then I saw that same Jacquire King thing & together all this made me think of how useful the VU is if you’re working in less than ideal bass monitoring environment - it really shows the bass energy in a pretty unique way. I like listening to references (check the bass VU on for instance Jon Castelli’s Khalid Talk vs Sza Low - one very kick focused & one super sub focussed - both a fuckton of low end vs Serban Blinding Lights try -7 as the reference - BL hovers around 0 & is louder lufs wise & then try Fleetwood Mac Dreams (I think the 2012 remaster) - softer, nice transients, beautiful bass - being driven by Kick,snare & bass) - all of those “dance” with the groove.

author: JustinLeu
content:
I think this is important to realize WHY this is working. The polarity flip is making the drums (as a whole) sum the waveforms in a more pleasing and additive way. 
The way I theorize this is happening is because while all of the drum mics relative phase relationships remain the same, the frequencies that the drums produces slightly vary during a performance. These are NOT one shot samples going through the microphones. The 4 on the floor makes it much more complex because BOTH the snare and the kick are producing different tones (with variances) at the same time…The frequencies that are additive (in-phase) are relative to all of the drum mics positioning/distance from the source, BUT different frequencies will add/subtract in magnitude…that is what we are quickly checking with polarity. If you change the tuning on a snare drum for instance, it can start to become less “in phase” with the overheads because the fundamental frequency has changed and may not be complimentary between the OH/SN mics anymore at the same distance.

author: Will Melones
content: I’ve had this with the relationship between kick in and overheads. It *looks* like the waveforms are opposing each other. And it makes sense—air pressure is pushed toward the kick in mic while it’s moving away from the overheads. But flipping the polarity sucks out all the low end. Sometimes that big bump at the beginning of the waveform may not be what you’re hearing as the fundamental. Just gotta trust your ears over your eyes. And air *isn’t* just moving away from the overheads, because the lowest frequencies are exploding outward in every direction, up and back into those mics as well.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
So think of mid vs side in terms of panning left right & center, and think of EQ as volume. 

If you’ve got a lot of low end information on the sides, and say it’s fighting with a mono bass track that’s supposed to be holding down the majority of the low end, you can eq the lows out of those panned tracks, or you can blanket turn all the lows down on the sides with a m/s eq on a buss, so that the L and R info is quieter. It’s basically a group volume ride for frequencies instead of tracks. You can also do this on individual stereo tracks if just panning isn’t granular enough. 

The why & when is mostly about taste. I tend to mix into a proQ3 setting that has the sides hi passed around 100 for the same reason I have a pultec boosting highs & lows on the master- it just ends up doing a lot of work for me.

It can become problematic if I’ve got big toms in a song and, after I’ve got a mix starting to cook I’ll toggle it on & off to see if I’m doing more harm than good. For the kind of music I mostly do, it works more often than not, but the one song I sent to Cian for mixing he basically blasted me for doing that. (In his own kind and gentle way.)

But m/s eq isn’t just for the master buss. You can think about it for any stereo track. Sometimes, I have an acoustic that’s carrying the whole song, but the fundamentals are fighting with the vocal, so I’ll turn the mid down at that frequency (or side chain that to the vocal if it feels anemic when the vocal is out.) that leaves the sides as big as you like cause it’s not fighting with my mono vocal.

content:
Here's what I did. 
Made session with a bunch of group channels. Namely these:
Kicks, Snares/Claps, High End Perc, All Drums, All Bass, All Music, LDV and BGV. 

Kicks, snares, percs was routed to the ALL Drums as well. Any transition FX was also routed to All Drums. 

On each of these groups I had an izotope insight 2 channel. 

I then loaded a bunch of stems and routed them to the proper channels. Some came with only a drum bus channel so I could check the kick and snare on their own. 

I set the levels so all mixes peaked at -4dB. 

Here's the songs I looked at:
100 Gecs - Stupid Horse
Ariana Grande - No Tears left to cry
The Weeknd - Blinding Lights
Charli XCX - Forever
Ava Max - Turn Off The Lights
Dua Lipa - New Rules
The 1975 - Give yourself a try

Here's what I found

author: f.ern___
content:
The All Drums group was pretty much consistent over all these tracks hitting peaks at -7dB and and RMS at -15 or 16. Ava max had peaks at -5. 

Most kicks had peaks at -9.5 to -10dB. Ava Maxs which is was more dance heavy peaked at -6. RMS on all stayed within the -14 to -16 range. 

Snares peaks was about 1dB louder than the kick on all tracks and ranged between 8.5 and 11. Rms sat between -22 and -24 on all. Ava Max is exluded cause there was a kick on the snare stem. 

High end percs had peaks around -20 to -25 and rms around -35-40. 

on the All BASS channel the peaks varied a bit more ranging between -8.5 and -12dB. Most sat between 8.5 and 10 though. For rms they were all around 15-16 apart from 1975 again hitting -18. 

The All Music Group all had an RMS of -18 to -20 but the peaks varied -6dB to -11dB

the LDV group (which sometimes also had the BGVs in the stem) varied more than I thought and had peaks between -7 and -14.5. Most sat around -10 to -12. Ava had the lowest ldv, possibly in favor for the stronger drums. On most tracks the RMS sat at -20.

BGV. The bgvs include to many different types of elements to draw any conclusion but they all had overall RMS between -21 and -25.

author: Zack Hames
content:
This has been a recent revelation for me as well!

For me, gently cutting midrange areas of build up on each instrument, like guitars, drum overheads/cymbals/keys, around 1-2k, leaves a nice little slot for the snare and vocals to sit.

My thought is all of those midrange elements are cumulative. It may sound too smooth in the midrange solo-ed, but when you have 3 elements each with a -2dB cut around 2k, you’re making a sort of “-6dB” hole for the vocal. In other words, you’ve got a giant 6dB mid spike if they all add up

author: Robin.Z.V
content:
Something I picked up today from Daniel Robert Ford and never thought about.

Slate Trigger 2 gate on a stereo kick track - **ALWAYS** use it in dual-mono mode and never in stereo. In stereo mode, Trigger 2 listens to the left side and the right side is your “Bleed” control. You’ll get a summed mono version based off of the left side and lose the stereo information.

author: Adam Thein
content:
All good it’s a little tricky at first and just really difficult to explain typed out for me.

Same concept as using a sidechain input from a kick drum to duck the 808 - an external sidechain allows us to give the compressor something to listen to and apply the compression from that source to another source.  When the kick is fed to a compressor on your 808 channel - the compressor “listens” to the kick and applies the compression curve from the kick onto the bass.

So in your case of printing stems with a mix bus compressor - you want the SPL Iron plugin to “listen” to the entire mix as it heard it before but then apply that compression to one track at a time.

We can do this in Ableton with some clever workarounds, which would be a lot more efficient to show you on a video call on the server if you are free later.  Essentially you need to print a version of your song at each point in your mix bus chain where there are dynamics plugins (just before the Slate plugin, just before the Iron Compressor but after all the other plugins) and then send that audio to those corresponding plugins’ external sidechain inputs and then you can use the “include return and master effects” and get the result you are looking for

content: Some badass feedback has already been given but something I have to remind myself of every day is to focus mostly on the drum buss and mic levels/polarity. if a frequency is killing you in one mic, it’s probably in most of the others. author: NoahNeedleman
content:
You might be making the whole thing too complicated. 

Are you currently working on a country song and feeling like the snare is competing with the vocal?

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Depth in a mix is fairly simple, if you can hear it. You have a few basic tools and a few more complex ones, but overall it looks like this. 

Brighter+louder=closer
Darker+quieter=further

This is also true for bottom end *mostly.*

Panning also pushes things out of the center and allows you to play with a lot more area in which to push things back. 

If you don’t have the luxury of panning, as with a snare drum, then you have volume & eq as your main tools. 

Then you have reverb. Shorter predelay, fewer short reflections & louder tails. Choosing a larger algo like a hall, etc.

author: NoahNeedleman
content: But! I might challenge you that in pop music, even in country, the snare plays a very prominent role, and probably should be the only thing as loud & as bright in the mix as the vocal.

author: Sei046
content:
I would definitely say the chain, say fx, pre, mic etc is almost inconsequential against the vocal performance. Every extra minute spent on trying to iron it all out there will save you hours in editing and mixing. I’ve often considered selling a piece of gear and then had a really stellar vocal go through only to realise there was nothing wrong with the gear. I’m sure you’re sick of reading it but the performance is everything. You can’t REALLY EQ air and body into a vocal that isn’t there. You can’t try simulate it alright. And you can’t create actual excitement with compression, just try and trick the brain into thinking there’s excitement. A 57 into any preamp into any interface with a stellar performance will sound amazing. 

After that is just treatment, and it’s essentially pointless discussing chains because it’s so song and vision dependant. 

A boring answer I know but you’ll save a lot of headache and heart ache the sooner you learn it. 

It’s like when you hear a new compressor plugin just explode a drum room and it sounds amazing. Analogue glue, explosive release, so much groove. And then you slap it on the lacklustre room and performance you actually have in front of you and it doesn’t seem to sound so amazing any more.

author: JustinLeu
content:
You could achieve the same numerical amount either way (no HPF or with HPF), the threshold would be different....but the same amount of compression is possible. 

What would be VERY different is how the compressed signal "feels" 

Think about what would happen if you keyed (side-chained) your mixbus compressor with the bass guitar vs if you keyed the compressor with just the snare drum. Given the same attack/release settings the entire mix would move differently.

Runing into this horrible issue with Trigger 2 plug. 

So every so often, a sample will be out of phase with the main signal i am triggering from. (let's say a kick drum)

well, it's not that it's actually flipping or anything. it's just being triggered slight late so it is phasing out with the original.

it happens *consistently* on certain hits! and the only fix i've found is to move the sample after committing if I am using an aux track, or moving the the trigger track to happen sooner.

changing buffer size doesn't seem to change anything. changing any settings in Trigger 2seemingly doesn't change anything.
